newsitem.title: USA: SoCal Edison to charge customers $5.8 mln.
newsitem.headline: SoCal Edison to charge customers $5.8 mln.

text.p: The California Public Utilities Commission (CPUC) approved on Wednesday a request by Edison International's Southern California Edison to charge its customers for $5.8 million of an investment in unused transmission facilities.
The $5.8 million is part of Edison's share of a $50 million project to build a transmission line and upgrade power stations near Victorville, Calif.
The facilities were built to transmit power generated by Luz International Ltd. and CalEnergy, but Luz filed for bankruptcy in 1991.
Up to that point, Edison had spent $17.1 million on the project, the CPUC said.
The commission said it authorized Edison to charge customers $5.8 million because the utility began the construction in good faith.
The CPUC also said Edison is expected to pursue reimbursement of its remaining $11.4 million investment through the bankruptcy courts.
But if it is unsuccessful in recovering any of this amount, Edison may again seek CPUC approval to collect the balance from ratepayers, the commission noted.
